docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN newly pregnant women visit Brigham Obstretrics and Gynecology, a practice affiliated with Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, they are handed a sheaf of primers on prenatal tests, morning sickness and the like. The tone is calm and brisk, but a page of recommended books carries a warning: ''*WE * DO * NOT * RECOMMEND * 'What to Expect When You're Expecting.''' In 1984, when ''What to Expect'' was first published, it was revolutionary -- an ''Our Bodies, Ourselves'' for pregnancy, written by women to reassure women who may have been afraid to call their obstetricians about embarrassing symptoms or who panicked when they woke up with odd cramps in the middle of the night. Since then it has become the bible of American pregnancy. With over 13 million copies in print, it is so established that it is handed out by doctors, insurance companies and even employers.

headline.main: Expecting Trouble: The Book They Love to Hate

docs.snippet: In 1984, when "What to Expect" was first published, it was revolutionary. But in its third decade, the book has come under regular criticism.

docs.lead_paragraph: Leading senators and former state and local government officials who have supervised the recovery from natural disasters agreed Wednesday that a single government official with emergency powers should be put in charge of reconstruction efforts after Hurricane Katrina. ''We're on a road to failure,'' warned Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, at the first Congressional hearing on the hurricane. He said President Bush should appoint a lead officer, ''the sooner the better.''

headline.main: Senate Panel Discusses Need for Central Authority in Recovery

byline.original: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and CARL HULSE

docs.lead_paragraph: Bait and Switch The (Futile) Pursuit of the American Dream By Barbara Ehrenreich 237 pages. Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt & Company. $24. Nobody reads Barbara Ehrenreich without developing a heightened sense of how American business operates. So readers of her new book, ''Bait and Switch,'' will notice how closely its publisher has made it conform to her last one, the best seller ''Nickel and Dimed.'' Their titles have the same ring. Ms. Ehrenreich uses the same basic investigative reporting methods. Perhaps inflation or an extra 16 pages accounts for a $1 rise in price.
docs.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews book Bait and Switch: The (Futile) Pursuit of the American Dream by Barbara Ehrenreich; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Barbara Ehrenreich goes undercover again and discovers that for the white-collar jobless, it's a jargon jungle out there.
